O w I i August /5 1913 Irmieu.iate .j Sir I am directed by Secretary Sir E. Grey to acknow ledge the receipt of your letter P.3230 of the 13th. instant respecting the further application made by Monsieur Menasche to ship arms and ammunition from Muscat to Jibuti. I am to state for the information of the Marquess of Crewe that Sir E. Grey concurs in the proposal to authorise the shipment on the conditions suggested in your letter, and. that he also agrees to the proposed instructions to the Government of India on the subject. I am. Sir Your most obedient humble Servant COPY TO INDIA ftie Under Secretary of State India Office.Draft.- U.S. of S. F.O. /&r<^ IMMEDIATE. Si r, n With reference to correspondence ending with your letter of the 8th July, No. 30645, respecting the arms traffic at Maskat, I am directed to invite attention to cation on the part of M. Menasche to ship arms and ammunition from Mashat to Jibuti. In all the circwnstances the Marquess of Crewe accepts, though with some reluctance, the view that there would he no advantage in pursuing for the present the question of the fraud committed by M.Menasche in May last; and he is prepared, if the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs concurs, to authorise the proposed further shipment, as recommended by the Government of India, on condition that the goods are sealed by the Warehouse Superintendent and placed by his officials on board the vessel direct from the Ware house, the Political Agent at Maskat being required to satisfy himself that this procedure is duly observed, and that an accur^- ate manifest is drawn up. The Gov eminent of India might r.oTi t 1th August 1913. comnunicated to the Viceroy's telegram of the 8th instant reporting a further appli- alsoalso be instructed to arrange for the inspection of the cargo by the Customs authorities at the first Indian port of call, and to consider whether, in the event of the full consignment not being found on board, steps could not be taken to detain the goods, leaving it to M* Menasche to take such action for their recovery as he may deem feasible.\ 4.0, 'I ^ 30 /'3 l From Viceroy, 8th August 1913. Foreign Secret. Arms traffic. Following from Political Agent, Muscat, dated 1st August:— “ Sultan has to-day received letter from French Consul asking leave for Menasche to ship more arms and ammunition from warehouse to Jibuti. No details are given in letter. “ Ordinarily I should propose that His Highness reply that he cannot possibly consider application until a satisfactory reply has been received to his letter of the 9th llajab, or until Menasche produces from his private warehouse one hundred and eight cases of good modern cartridges which will be examined by warehouse superintendent, and shipped under seal with Other arms and ammunition on board steamer by warehouse officials. “ Possibly, however, in view of negotiations re compensation, it may be thought advisable to drop complaint and merely ship goods under proper precautions.” Cox supports the proposal contained in the last paragraph. We agree, and propose to issue instructions accordingly. At present stage of nego tiations little is to be gained by attempting to get satisfaction for Menasche’s misdeeds, while it is to our advantage to reduce stocks.In any further communication on this subject, please quote no. 50645/15. and address— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, London. f o | J j r,* » ■ ”7 | Foreign Office July 8 th, 1913. Wed late. Sir: - I am directed by Secretary Sir S. Grey to acknowledge the receipt of your letters of the 3rd and 4th instant (P. 2607) respecting the Arms Traffic at Muscat. I am to state for the information of the lii-Q, rquess of Gr ewe that Sir E. Grey is disposed to concur in the sugges tions made in the Viceroy’s telegram of July 3rd with regard to the proposed sale to the dheikh of Mohammerah of arms and ammunition shipped to Muscat by Messrs. Kynoch and Me s srs. Laubenburg. While agreeing to the proposals made on this point Sir E. Grey is doubtful whether any useful purpose would now be served by making representations to the French Government respecting the action of the French Consul in connexion with the recent fraud on the part of Menach6. It is understood that if the proposed transaction with the Sheikh of Mohammerah is arranged on the terms indicated e Under Secretary of State, India Office. Q i L the T'j&cZv -n IN'UA 11 JUL1913 SECRETARY'S N2 28cy (30645/15 the questions at issue with Abdur Rahim Jafar and Ali Khan would be settled, but in any case it would appear that a complaint at Paris would probably not be productive ol any good result, while to start a discussion on a point 01 til is kind might have an unfavourable effect on the general negotiations. I am, bir, Your most obedient, humble ServantFrom Viceroy, 3rd July 1913. Foreign Secret Please see my telegrams of 20th and 28th June, Menasche. Following telegrams repeated. (!•) From Knox No. 95, dated 28th June “ Agent of Sheikh of Mohammerah now at Maskat needs over a 1,000 Mauser lilies with approximately 700,000 rounds of ammunition, also Martini Henry ammunition 300,000 approximately. If Faubenhurg and Kynoch aie piepaied to accept invoice value 'plus moderate profit thereon please inform me of rate required by telegraph when I hope to be able to dispose of all then existing stocks of arms and ammunition in warehouse provided that it is understood that they abandon all claims against Abdul Rahim Jafar and All Khan and also authorise me to deduct from the purchase money these two parties’ deposits. “ British firms involved will have to deal direct with agent of Louis Dieu as regards agency rights, as he has declined to explain his latest apparent breach of faith and I am obliged to decline relations with him. (Addressed to Foreign and repeated to Political Resident, Persian Gruff in continuation of my telegram of 15th June fast No. 85).” (2.) From Cox No. 1158, dated 28th J une : — “ Muscat. Telegram No. 95. These are part of consignment referred to in Foreign Department telegram No. 289 D, dated 21st January for which Minister has approved grant of facilities, as before. Supposing that agent of Sheikh of Mohammerah is prepared to purchase stocks in question adoption of course suggested by Political Agent seems convenient and I support p roposals.” We consider Political Agent’s proposals afford a favourable opportunity for reducing stocks and trust it will be possible to persuade firms concerned to accept them.In any further communication on this subject, please quote No. 9102 / 13 . and address— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, London. Sir:- Foreign Office June 30 , 1913. I am directed dy Secretary Sir E.Grey to acknow ledge the receipt of your letter P,2468 of the 24th instant, respecting the order for arms and ammunition placed with Monsieur Menasche hy the Deputy Governor of Bunder Abbas. As regards the question of the proposed transfer of the stocks of British firms from a French to a British Agent Sir E.Grey concurs in the views expressed hy the Marquess of Crewe. He also agrees that the pur chase of arms from Menasche might in the circumstances he allowed, and has no suggestions to make in the matter unless it is considered that the consent to the proposed transaction might he made conditional on Menasche's making good the fraud committed hy him in connection i l 0 with the arms which he was allowed to ship to Europe ^ I am, Sir, 27 U Your most obedient, humble Servant, 'he Under Secretary of State, India Office._ ., t I ~L Put away witn .^1^. From Viceroy, 2&th June 1913. Foreign Secret. Please see your telegram dated 11th June regarding Menasche. Sultan of Muscat addressed French Consul and the latter has refused to give a definite reply until the claims between Menasche and Abdur Rahim Jafar, vide correspondence forwarded with Foreign Secretary’s weekly letter No. 12 M., dated 20th March, have been settled. This action appears to afford Sultan fresh justification for forcibly searching Menasche’s premises, and confiscating stocks in question or the equivalent thereof. We consider action of French Consul should be brought to the notice of French Government, in view of the fact that he expressly agreed to conditions which have been broken by Menasche. M e propose to defer recommendations as to what, if any, reply should be made to French Consul by Sultan until we receive instructions from you on our telegram dated 20th June.t From Viceroy, 20th June 1913. Foreign Secret. Your telegram of 11th June. Purchase of arms for Deputy Governor, Bunder Abbas. It is difficult to place order with British firms, as all British stocks in warehouse are consigned to Menasche. Possibly British firms if consulted could suggest a solution, and in any case could they not be informed that it is difficult to assist them until the} 7 change their agent to a British subject, who will deal with the feultan through British Consul ? It appears from this case, and from fact that consignment recently shipped by Menasche to Jibuti contained arms and ammunition of English manufacture, that claims of the French affect British merchandise to con siderable extent. Consequently French claims to compensation would be reduced if British firms withdrew their goods from Menasche.Kxi^-gO 25) In any further communication on this subject, please quote no . 25654/13 • j; Foreign Office and address— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, London. 9th* June, 1913 Sir imediate. With reference to your letter P.2179-80 of June 4th. re lating to the Arms Traffic at Muscat, I am directed by Secretary Sir E. Grey to inform you that he concurs in the Marquess of Crewe’s suggestion to approve Sir P. Cox’s pro posal that enquiry should be made of the French Consul re garding Monsieur Menasche’s apparent breach of faith; he also concurs in the suggestion that the arms in question should, if possible, be confiscated. Sir E. Grey agrees with His Lordship in thinking that it would be advisable to refuse permission to a local arms dealer to purchase arms and ammunition from French private warehouses for sale to the Deputy Governor, Bunder Abbas; and that it would be better that the latter should be private ly advised to cancel the order, and place it with Messrs. Laubenburg. Sir E. Grey likewise concurs in Lord Crewe’s suggestion le Under Secretary of State India Office. q q p y t o |' 'M / i 13 JUN1913 | SECT. Ml ARY‘S N/JM ■#'**% S* : IH From, Viceroy, 31st May 1913. Foreign Secret. Following telegram lias been received from Political Agent, Maskat, regarding arms. Menasehe was permitted to reship from warehouse for Europe and Jibuti (vide your telegram of 21st January). “ S.S. “ Alumna” sailed yesterday for Karachi, taking for Antwerp 38 cases rifles and 16 cases cartridges and for Jibuti 20 cases of rifles and 300 cartridge boxes. Menasche withdrew 7 from warehouse 48 cases of rifles and 424 cases of ammunition. He has thus, it appears, added 10 cases of rifles and withheld 108 cases of cartridges and apparently never sent them at all, unless he did so by Russian S.S. “ Vesta ” that arrived here yesterday and left the same evening for Aden. Shoik-h directed warehouse superintendent leave the matter of shipment to the Customs Department who seem to have left Menasche free hand. Towell & Co.’s clerk noticed many cases left behind in the boat that took consignment to the “Almeria.” His Highness is much exercised about this non-shipment and told me that he watched French loading a small boat after the “ Almeria ” left but he does not know whether it was sent to the Russian or elsewhere. I do not doubt His Highness’s good faith, though his Customs Department employes cannot be relied upon. I propose that His Highness should address French Consul officially asking for an explanation of discrepancy between number of cases withdrawn from warehouse and numbers shipped. Sultan agrees, but it seems advisable that letter should be sent as soon as possible as it is possible that Menasche has tricked French Consul also.” Though we have hitherto kept French Consul out of transaction, Cox considers it advisable in view of fresh developments to take course suggested by Political Agent. We agree with Sir P. Cox in view of fact that French firm have evaded rules and broken conditions accepted (vide Consul’s letter of 7th March to Sultan forwarded with Foreign Secretary’s weekly letter No. 14 M, dated 3rd April). From subsequent report it appears that fraud committed by Menasche is more extensive than stated by Political Agent. Enquiries are proceeding. We should be glad of early instructions in this case and on points referred to in my telegram of even date. hlfcWL/ X.| 'W: From Viceroy, 31st May 1913. Foreign Secret. Maskat arms. Political Agent at Maskat has made following proposals: (1) That local arms dealer should be permitted to puichase certain arms and ammunition from French private warehouses for sale to Deputy-Crovernor, Bunder Abbas. (2) idiat two Arab merchants should be permitted to purchase from Menasche 750,000 rounds of ammu nition now 7 detained in warehouse. This ammunition, if purchased, would be subject to warehouse rides, and available for requirements of Omanis. Cox telegraphs as follows regarding these proposals :— “ These concessions to expediency and the french dealers go much against the grain to me, but as Government consider that disadvantages involved are more than counterbalanced, they will, I think, wish to adopt present suggestions for further reducing stocks.” Acceptance of first proposal is open to objection that we have consistently refused to allow Sheikhs of Koweit and Mofiammerah to purchase from private stocks, that warehouse rules are being further weakened by each relaxation, and that such action makes it difficult to reply to complaints of inconsistency and differentiation in favour of French, such as that put forward by Messrs. Kynoch, Limited. On the other hand, as we have now a fair measure of control over imports, and as His Majesty’s Government recently decided (vide your telegram of 14th March last) that advantage of reducing stocks in Maskat outweighed objections mentioned above, presume that proposal should be approved, as destination of arms appeai-s unobjectionable. As regards (2) we see no strong objection to the proposal, as ammunition will be disposed of under warehouse rules.I Enclosv <,\J 14 43 ■i-O iVJAi i C\ ft t v vr ,U' p L Telegram, No. 432 A , dated the 25th (received 26th) April 1913. From—The Finance Department, Simla, To—The Comptroller of India Treasuries, Calcutta. Please arrange for payment of Es. 30,000 to Sultan of Maskat at Maskat Treasury. 44 No. 1284, dated Bushire, the 20th (received 28th) April 1913 (Confidential). From— Lieutenant- Colonel Sir P. Z. Cox, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, To—The Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department. With, reference to the correspondence ending with Foreign Department endorsement No. 844 D.,* dated 27th * Semi No. 224 , Part xm. March 1913, on the subject of the desire of the Maskat arms-dealer, Menasche, to re-export the stock of arms and ammu nition lying in his private godown, I have the honour to forward, by post, as the No. 61, dated 1211 ! April 1913. matter does not seem to be pressing No. 382, dated 17 th April 1913 . copies of two telegrams, from the Political Agent, Maskat, reporting the action by him, in pursuance of Government s instructions, and the result. I should have thought that His Highness the Sultan could have found means through one of his arms-dealing friends to sound Menasche in a way, which need not have let him in for a rebuff, and would have afforded more chance of success than the course followed, but, in the circumstances explained, I presume that His Majesty’s Government will wish Mons. Menasche to be permitted to re-export his arms, without passing them through the ware ouse. I must admit, however, that the proceeding presents itself to me as a sacrifice or principle to expediency, which is weakening to the Sultan’s position and ours, ■ and inconvenient from other points of view. Telegram P., No. 61, dated (and received) the 12th April 1913. From—The Political Agent, Maskat, To—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. With reference to t Serial No. 7. ^ decision, which had been arrived at. We arranged between us, at my suggestion, that Gumming of Messrs. Towel! & Co. should be asked by me to communicate the procedure, which is propose o Menasche • that is, that, in accordance with rule 1, the arms and ammunition, which he proposes to ship from his private warehouse must first be Drought n tie warehouse, when the enforcement of rule 2 would be warved by the Sultan Gumming has now written to me to say that, m regard to the arms, which Ivino- in^his private warehouse, Menasche has made a flat refusal to have anything”to*do with the warehouse. It is as well, I venture to thmk, that the Sultan was not exposed to a direct refusal. The course, which was proposed in my telegram No. 288^of 17^ arc^, j Serial No. 211 , Part xiu. There is no hurry, as it has not yet been. ^finitelv settled by Menasche how much he will ship, and Gumming has no d n= t nf the steamer Menasche has made an agreement to pay a minimum frefeht/irrespective of the quantity shipped, though should he ship more than the freight covers he will pay more.15 Telegram, No. 382, dated the 17th April 1913. From —The Political Agent, Maskat, To The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. My telegram, dated 12th April, 61. I now hear definitely that the expected steamer has refused to call Maskat, and that nothing is known of an- other calling. 45 Telegram, No. 770, dated the 26th (received 28th) April 1918. From—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, To—The Foreign Secretary, Simla. Your telegram* of 25th April, 81 S. At my request, and with concurrence of Naval Commander-in-Chief, Senior * Serial No. 39. Naval Officer, Persian Gulf Division, has been asked to specify evidence showing that rifles were jettisoned. Will telegraph views on receipt of his reply. 46 Telegram P., No. 90 S., dated the 29th April 1913. From—The Foreign Secretary, Simla, To—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire (repeated to the Political Agent, Maskat). Please refer to your telegram No. 742,+ dated the 20th April. In part pay- riease reioi to y 0 ^ promised to Sultan, Rs. t Serial No. 27 . 30,000 may now be paid to His Highness.54 Telegram P., No. 100 S., dated the 5th May 191S. From—The Foreign Secretary, Simla, To—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Eushire (repeated to Maskat). Reference vour letter No. 1284,* dated the 20th April. In circumstances, * Serial No. 44 . not insist on compliance with Hule 1. That there are objections to withdrawing demand originally made, and to weakening of Sultan’s position, which would thereby be involved, we fully recognise, but the importance of reducing, by every possible means, existing stocks of arms in Maskat appears to outweigh these disadvantages. Sultan should be advised accordingly. We leave it to your discretion as to the method and time of conveying decision to Menasche,57 Telegram,'''No. 818, dated the 7th (received 8th) May 1913, From—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, To—The Foreign Secretary, Simla. Your telegram No. 965 E.-A. of 2nd May. The prayer of the firm to His Majesty’s Foreign Office is that the release of the arms should he brought about. T suggest that we should simplv inform them that we have advised the Sultan to release the arms, which would he subject to the application of Rules 7 to 12 (para.) Only one type of consignees is mentioned in form B, and if J)ieu is admitted by the documentary consignee be is the person to whom the intimation of release should be made by the Sultan. For this reason, and because wo do not intend to intervene between the firm and their consignees, there seems no need to require au affidavit, or to ask Sultan to sound the native Clears as to whether they will take delivery. Addressed Foreign; repeated Mask at by post.'er f r ' 5i F*' 17 •-^Tv, hidla 24 APR iyi3 rj •r 25 ^ V< *«^ Telegram P., No. 22, dated the 16th AywaLl^ l^. *- ■ >' j From—His Excellency the Naval Commander-in-Chief, To—The Secretary to the Government of India, Marine Department (repeated to the Political Resident, Persian Gulf). On the 6th instant, the Senior Naval Officer in the Persian Gulf sent me the following telegram and repeated it to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. On the 3rd April, a badan was captured off Ras Maidani by H. M. S. f< Pelorus ”. She was bound to Habibulla from Muttra and bad no papers. She carried 50 rifles and ammunition which were jettisoned before the man-of- war could reach the badan. The crew and the badan have been taken to Jask. With your concurrence, I propose to fine the Nakhoda, imprison crew who were implicated, and destroy the ha dan by fire. 26 Telegram P., No. 62, dated (and received) the 19th April 1913. From—The Political Agent, Maskat, To—The Foreign Secretary, Simla. Sultan of Maskat requests that, in consequence of recent heavy charges on him, he may be paid in cash at Maskat a sum of Rs. 30,000 in part pay ment of the lakh of rupees promised to him as a lump sum in ^ May last, in consideration of loss of revenue prior to warehouse negotiations. I beg to support His Highness’s request, and to solicit early sanction to payment of this sum, as nothing has yet been paid on this account. This treasury can meet the amount asked for without difficulty. Addressed to Resident, Bushire. 27 27 Telegram P., No. 742, dated (and received) the 20th April 1913. From—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, To—The Foreign Secretary, Simla (repeated to Political Agent, Maskat). Please see the telegram* from Knox, No. 62, dated the 19th instant. I support the request of His Highness with » Semi No. 26 . reference to my telegram No. 910, dated the 31st August 1912.28 t {Confidential.) Translation of a lettter from His Highness the Sultan of Maskat, to the address of the hrench Consul, Maskat, dated the 1st Jamadi-al-Awwal (9th April 1913). (2oth January 1913), and repeat to Your Honour that, before the settlement of the question of the new regulations, I am unable to add anything to my letter.— Usual endbig, o j Translation forwarded with the respectful compliments of the undersigned to the Hon’ble the Secretary to the Government of India in the foreign Department. A copy has also been forwarded to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. Reference .—Foreign Department telegram ij: No. 674 D., dated 13th March + Enclo., Serial Xo. 144, Part XIII. I ask of Your (26th January 1913), and in this matter I ask of Your Honour a reference to my letter,f dated the 18th Safar 1331 H. Paisal bin Ttjbki. Endorsement No. 57 of 1913. J Serial No. 194, Part XIII. 3913, to the address of the Political Resi dent in the Persian Gulf. S. G. Knon, Major, Fo'iiical Agent and H, JB. M.’s Consul Maskat,**fflE*B 4» g /\PR ^ ‘f rfii No. 879, dated Bushire, the 16th March 1913 (Confidential). From— Lieutenant-Colonel Sir P. Z. Cox, K. C. I. E., C. S. I., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, To—The Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department. With reference to my telegram No. 383, dated 4th March, and to India No. 46, dated 8th March 1913 . ?* ce telegram dated the 14th instant, /toh) 1 have the honour to enclose, for the m- v 1 ' formation of the Government of India, a copy of the marginally cited letter, received from the Political Agent at Maskat, giving cover to a translation of a letter from the Prench Consul at Maskat to His Highness the Sultan, in which the conditions imposed by the latter for the shipment of arms to Jibuti or Europe from stocks in the special warehouse are accepted. Enclosure. No. 45, dated Maskat, the 8th March 1913 (Confidential). From— Major S. G. Knox, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul, Maskat, To —Lieutenant-Colonel Sir P. Z. Cox, K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. With reference to correspondence ending with your telegram No. 383, dated 4th March 1913, to the Eoreign Department and repeated to me, I have the honour to forward herewith copy in duplicate of the translation of a letter dated 7th March 1913, from the Erench Consul, Maskat, to His Highness the Sultan of Maskat, in which the former accepts on behalf of Monsieur Men- asche, Agent of Messrs. Louis Dieu, the conditions imposed by His Highness for the shipment of arms from stocks in the warehouse to Jibuti or Europe. Sub-Enclosure. Translation oj Arabic letter dated 7th March 1913, from French Consul, MasTcat, to Mis Highness the Sultan of Mashat. After compliments. —I have been honoured in the receipt oi your honoured * Presumably meant for His Highness’ letter letter dated the 24th* of Safar = lst Feb- dated isth Safar=26th January 1913. ruary 1913, about the license to your servant Menasche for the despatch of some arms to Jibuti or Europe. Now the aforesaid has returned from Basrah and accepted the conditions which you mentioned-in the close of your letter, and he says that the ship by which he wishes to load them will arrive next month, and at the time of its arrival he will load therein whatever he wishes from the aforesaid goods and we are obliged to Your Highness and greeting. Lsual ending. A. JEANNIEB. S. G. P. I., Delhi— No. 141 F. D.1In any further communication on this subject, please quote No . 14110/13. and address— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Oliice, London. Foreign Office mine di at 6. Sir: - With reference to your letter P.1125 of the 27th instant respecting Monsieur Louis Dieu's desire to re-ship stocks of amis now held hy him at Muscat to Jibuti and Antwerp, I am directed by Secretary Sir E. Grey to inform you that he concurs in the Marquess of Crewe’s proposal to approve the course suggested bv the Government of India in their telegram of the The Under Secretary of State, India Office. 23rd instant, on the understanding that compliance bv Monsieur Dieu with No.l of the sultan's regulations is not pressed as a sine qua non I sm, Your most obedient, humble Servant,F —' U.Ati i b 1 No. 202, dated Maskat, the 20th February 1913. V. S 25/3 From— Major S. G. Knox, C. I. E., Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's To—The Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department, Delhi. I have the honour to forward, herewith, for information, a copy of my letter No. 201, dated the 20th February 1913, with enclosures, which 1 have addressed to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, on the subject of the shipment of arms from Maskat to Djibouti or Antwerp. Enclosure. p rom —M ajor S. G. Knox, C.I.E., Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's To— Lieutenant-Colonel Sir P. Z. Cox, K. C. I. E.,!C. S, I., Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. I have the honour to forward, herewith, copies of correspondence between Messrs. Towell & Co. and myself on the subject of the shipment of arms from Maskat to Antwerp or Jibuoti and to request the favour of early instruc tions on the point raised in paragraph 3 of my letter No. 200, dated the 20th February 1913, to Messrs. Towell & Co., viz., whether I may advise His Highness to permit the reshipment to Djibouti or Europe of arms and ammunition now stored in private godowns and whether I am myself to grant all reasonable facilities for such reshipment. 2. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Hon’ble the Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department. Sub-Enclosure No. 1. From— Messrs. W. J. Towell & Co., Maskat Agents for Hamburg-Amerika Line, To-Major S. G. Knox, C. I. E, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's We have the honour to request your guidance in the following matter : Sub-Enclosure No. 2. No. 200, dated Maskat, the 20th February 1913. From-MAJOB, S. G. Ksox, Political Agent and His Britonnio Majesty's Consul Consul, Maskat, No. 201, dated Maskat, the 20th February 1913. Consul Maskat, No. 108, dated the 19th February 1913. Consul, Maskat. could in any way cause detention to the steamer. Maskat, To —Messrs. Towel & Co., Agents for Hamburg-Amerika Line, Maskat.2 from Maskat to Djibouti or Europe of 19 cases rifles and 521 cases ammuni tion which (E. & O. E.) are now lying in the Maskat Arms Warehouse and that on my part, I have received specific instructions from higher authority to orant all facilities in regard to this particular shipment, provided the packages are taken direct from the Arms Warehouse to the exporting steamer after such inspection of the packages and their contents as the consignor may ^ desire. 3. As regards the question of shipments from this port to Djibouti and Antwerp of arms at present lying in private godowns, I have at present no instructions, but your request is being transmitted without delay to higher authority, and I think I may promise you a definite reply before the middle of March. Should greater despatch be desired, I shall be happy to telegraph your request if you or the consignors are prepared to pay for the cost of the telegrams.' all Nt s roviil ?3 iiiaj of k No. ^10, dated Maskat, the 22nd February 1913. rrom __MAJOU S. Gr. Knox, C. I. E., Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty s Consul, Maskat, To—The Secretary to the Government, of India in the Foreign Department, Delhi. In continuation of my letter No.^l^, dated the 20th February 1912, on the subiect of the shipment of arms from Maskat to Djibouti or Antwerp I LTe the honour to forward a copy of my letter Na 211 dated the 22nd February 1913, with its enclosure, which I have addressed to t o 1 Kesident in the Persian Gulf on the subject. Enclosure. No. 211, dated the 22nd February 1913. From—The Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat, To—The Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. In continuation of my letter no. 201, dated the 20 * Debma^lS, on the subject of the shipment of arms DomMaskattoDjiboutaor An p I have the honour to forward a copy of letter No^ 109 dated the /m re y 1913 which I have received from Messrs. W. J. Towell & Co. on the subject^ o * c01)v 0 f this letter, with its enclosure, has been forwarded to the Hon’ble the Secretary to the Government of India m the Foreign epar men . Sub-Enclosure. No. 109, dated the 21st February 1913. From-MBisas. W. J. Towei.l & Co, Maskat, Agents for Hamburg-Amerika Line, T 0 Major S. G. Knox, C. I. E„ Political Agent and His Bntann.c Majesty s Consul, Maskat. om-n We have the honour to acknowledge receipt of your letter No. 200 of 20th instant and thank you for the information contained therein. As the steamer will not call in until ^wly oW consider it will he necessary to as you o SP g ’ of ^ rmg at present lying in to do, for information regarding t _ P to receive later your instructions private godowns. We sh , a11 be f t Q° issue shipping orders for such cargoes in this connection as we do not care to issue snippi g without your sanction. HI F,p From Viceroy, 23rd March 1913. Foreign Secret. Your telegram of 14th March. Maskat arms. The suggestions communicated in my telegram of the 12th March were based on following considerations First, arms in question are in open market, having paid customs duty. We have consistently declined to permit Sheikhs of Mohammerah and Koweit from making (? to make) purchases from these arms on ground that they would leave Maskat without the warehouse mark, and that if permission were given to export arms in this way, rules introduced by Sultan with our support would be stultified. Secondly, attitude of French merchants has weakened considerably owing to long delay in settlement, and their desire to realise their money, and it seems possible that they might he tempted to accept Sultan’s terms in respect of arms in private godowns, having accepted them through medium of French Consul in regard to arms in warehouse. 'This view receives support from following telegram, dated 20th March, received from Cox. “ Craufurd’s Arms Traffic diary, dated 15th March, reports that Gognyer’s son has just left Muscat in a very despondent mood. Craufurd further states that Menachi’s stock, which he estimates at 10,000 weapons, is mostly composed of Sniders and similar weapons which he has failed.to find market for locally, and he has apparently no ammunition for the above rifles. Craufurd believes that if he were dealt with directly by the Sultan he would willingly pass arms through the warehouse if the Sultan, on the grounds that they have already paid duty, exempted them from further charges. “ By this pro forma compliance the principles of the rules would be preserved, and no ground afforded to other traders to complain of differential treatment.” In the circumstances we agree with Sir P. Cox, that it would be advisable to try course suggested in our telegram of the 12th March in the first instance, omitting the intervention of French Consul. Inconvenient weakening of rules which would be difficult to explain to other interested parties would thus be avoided. Further suggestion that Rule 1 should be held to apply to arms now intended for sale to public within Sultan s dominions, and not to arms thus reshipped seems inconsistent with attitude which we have adopted regarding application of Rule 4 to arms transhipped m Maskat territorial waters (vide your telegram of 18th March). In event of attempt failing recourse could be had to procedure which you suggest. M e lecognise objections to making a demand which it may be necessary 7 to withdiaw from, but the chances of success appear sufficient to justify experiment.DRAFT TELEGRAM. India F.O.C.C. SECRETARY OF STATE TO VICEROY, FOREIGN DEPARTMENT. (Retamilla) Repeat to Political Resident, Bush ire. Foreign secret. Your telegram 12th instant. Muscat. Seeing that whole difficulty is caused by comply with them merely for the purpose of reshipping to Europe or Jibouti, and will not insistence on rule 1 defeat object described rule 1 be held to apply only to arms now intended for sale to and ndt to arms thus reshipped? Further, is it necessary to intro und if arms are once on their way to Jibouti does it matter to us or Sultan who they belong to do provided that no claim fmr compen sation is admitted in respect of French refusal to recognise Sultan's rules are they likely to in your last sentence? Could not public within Sultan's dominions duce French consul into transaction, them. 12304. I. 2429. 500.—11/1911From Viceroy, \2th March 1913. Foreign Secret. Your telegram of 21st January last regarding shipment of french arms from Muscat. Powell & 0o.\-Agents, Hamburg-America line desire to ship by middle of April arms and ammunition belonging to Louis Dieu & Co., at present stowed in private godown, to Djibouti and Antwerp. We agree with Cox that the Sultan should be advised to inform French Consul of the request and to say if the Agent of Louis Dieu will first comply with Rule 1, and that if French Consul will certify that arms so transferred from the private godown to the warehouse are the bond fide property of the firm and represent whole of their stock in Oman, then Suitan will waive penalty under Rule 2 and permit re-shipment as in case, referred to in Maskat letter No. 18, 26th January, copy of which was sent you with Foreign Secretary’s weekly letter, 13th February 1913. It is obviously desirable to reduce Maskat stocks by every possible means.—- I?*- JL C 1913 Enclosure *'sr frv, ~\ p~ ■ A'r • 7 , 1 ], fJ uU r Xo. '20, datedMaskat^ the 2Gth January 1913 (Confidential). Prom—M ajor S. G. Knox, His Britannic Majestj^s Consul and Political Agent* Maskat, To—The Honourable Lieutenant-Colonel Sir A. H. McMahon, G.C.V.O., K.C.I.Ev C.S.I., Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department, Delhi. I have the honour to submit herewith copies of two letters Nos. 18 and 19, dated the 26th January 1913, which I have addressed to the Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf. Enclosure From No. IS, dated Maskat, the 26th January 1913 (Confidential). Major S. G. Knox, His Britannic Majesty’s Consul and Political Agent, Maskat, To Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Percy Cox, I.A., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. With reference to telegraphic correspondence, ending with your No. 153, dated 25th January 1913, I have the honour to submit herewith the translation of a letter which will issue to-day from His Highness the Sultan of Maskat to the address of the French Consul, Maskat, on the subject of the removal of certain arms, property of the French trader, Monsieur Menasche, agent of Messrs. Louis Lieu and Company, from the Arms’ Warehouse, Maskat, for direct shipment to Jibutil or Europe. I would invite a reference to the enclosure to letter dated 3rd January 1913 from the French Consul, Maskat, to His Highness the Sultan of Maskat, forwar ded under cover of this office endorsement No. 8-9, dated 6th January 1913. There is a slight discrepancy in the number of the 35 c/s of cartridges ex S.S. Eld) at ana- Itwill he noticed that the numbers run, according to Monsieur Menasche from 8047 to 8079 which gives a total of only 33 c/s, 25 c/s only were handed to the Superintendent of the Arms’ ‘Warehouse which leaves 8 c/s still unaccounted for. Of these 8 c/s, 4 were delivered in error by the Customs Superintendent to Ali Moosa, who, His Highness and the Superintendent of Customs assure me, admits his responsibility for these four c/s. M ith regard to the remaining 4, the Superintendent of Customs contends that they were short landed and that the Hamburg-Amerika Company is responsible H is exceed ingly unfortunate that there should he this trifling discrepancy hut I think it well to mention it, though I hope to find it a mere matter or detail, easily adjustable. 3. A copy of this letter is being forwarded to the Honourable the Secretary of the Government of India in the Foreign Department. Sub-Enclosure. Enclosure to letter No. 18, dated 2 6tk January 1913, from Political Agent, Maska^ to the address of the Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty s Consul-General m the Persian Gulf, Busliire. Translation of letter dated 18th Safar 1331 II.-26th January 1913, from Ills Highness the Sultan of Maskat, to the French Consul, Maskat. After compliments .—Your honoured letter dated the 3rd of January 1913 has reached me and your friend has understood whp is in the matter of loss which your honour mentions I have not himei to consented to your claim for the right of compensation m the matter of my new arrange ments concerning arms and on this subject I can say not A.nd in the matter of the request of Monsieur Menasche that he may take out some of the merchandise which belongs to him in the warehouse m order that he mfv send it to Jibuti or Europe I grant him permission but after Menasche comes to the Warehouse and inspects the merchandise w nch he wishes to take out for despatch and the goods shall be sent direct from thewarehouse to the ship in which they will be loaded. He cannot remove them to his private warehouse. Usual ending. True translation. S. G. KNOX, Major, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat. Enclosure 2. No. 19, dated Maskat, the 26th January 1918 (Confidential). -Major S. (1. Kxox, Political Agent and His Bivtannic Majesty’s Consul, From Maskat, To— Lieutenant-Colonel Sir P. Z. Cox, I.A., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Resident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. With reference to Foreign Department telegram No. 52-C., dated 24th January 1913, I have the honour to submit herewith the translation of a letter which will issue today from His Highness the Sultan of Maskat, to the address of the French Consul, Maskat, on the case between Menasche and Abdul Hahim Jafir. This translation will be found as enclosure 1 to this report. 2. Since my letter No. 5, dated 6th January 1913, was despatched to you, His Highness the Sultan of Maskat has been good enough to show me three more letters from the French Consul, Maskat, of which I have prepared translations which I am submitting to you as enclosure No. 2 to this report. It is not easy to follow the details of these various cases which overlap each other, more specially as I am anxious to avoid arousing the susceptibilities of His Highness in cases which are within his competence where my position is a somewhat delicate one. I would invite special attention to the last letter of the series where at first sight it struck me as somewhat high handed action on the part of the French Consul to support Monsieur Menasche in withholding payment of Customs dues in order to extort somewhat shadowy claims by Monsieur Menasche against His Highness’ Customs and His Highness’ subjects. On fuller enquiry, however, it would seem that, on the “ Beati possidentes ” principle, there is not much to complain of as Abdur Hahim Jafir, His Highness’subject, admittedly holds 24,000 francs’ worth of goods belonging to Monsieur Menasche’s principals, for which he has not paid. Monsieur Menasche further claims against him for about Hs. 5,675 against which Abdul Hahim wishes to write off so much earnest money, while m addition there is a matter of a claim against the arms dealer, Wram, for another Hs. 5,000 approximately. 3. I venture therefore to express the opinion that we can well afford to let matters rest with the despatch to the French Consul of enclosure No. 1 and await.further developments. 4. A copy of this letter, with its accompaniments, is being forwarded to the Hon’ble the Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department. Sub-Enclosure 1. Enclosure 1 to letter No. 19, dated 26th January 1913, from the Political Ao-ent Maskat to the address of the Political Resident and His Britannic Maiestv’s Cons?il-Geiipr-il it! the Persian Gulf, Bushire. ' ^ Translation of letter dated 18th of Safar 1331 H.~26th January 1913, from His Highness the Sultan of Maskat, to the French Consul, Maskat. After compliments .—Your honoured letter dated the 18th Muharram 1331 H, 28th December 1912, and your friend has understood all that you have mentioned therein. And with reference to the merchandise arriving in the ship Aimer i a, I mean to say, before the new arrangement, looking to the Ion o’ standing current customs of the country, I am unable to admit responsibilityon the part of my customs administration. And in the matter of the earnest money for the goods which came from Maskat after the new arrangement, it is necessary first of all that we should know how the decision will turn in the whole question of the matter of the new regulations between ourselves and the Glorious French Government and afterwards we will give our decision in the dispute between Menasche and Abdur Rahim in regard to this matter of detail. Usual ending. True translation, S. G. KNOX, Major, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat. Enclosure '2 (1st letter) to letter No. 19, dated 26th January 1918, from the Political Agent, Maskat, to the address of the Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire, Translation of letter dated 6th Safar J?>31 H. — 14th January 1913, from French Consul, Maskat, to the address of His Highness the Sultan of Mask at. After compliments. —I have been honoured in the arrival of your letter dated the 4th of Safar and your friend has understood what you mention therein. Now Menasche says that the thousand rupees are from an account apart from that between him and the other party and this thousand is detained with Humza on behalf of me and Your Highness and it is not possible to pay it except with the permission of bolh parties. As, for my part, I have given him leave that he should pay it to Menasche and he asks from you that you also should give him leave to pay it to him. And your servant Menasche wants to go to Basra and he would be exces sively obliged to Your Highness if you would favour him with a reply about all his claims and particularly about the goods which he wishes to send to Jibuti. And we have informed him that he should pay the duty which the Superintendent of Customs has claimed from him and to-day or to-morrow he will go to pay that sum. Usual ending. A. JEANNIER True translation. S. G. KNOX, Major, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat. Sub-Enclosure 2. Enclosures (2nd letter) to letter No. 19, dated 26th January 1913, from the Political Agent, Maskat, to tlie Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty s Consul-General m the Persian Gulf, Bushire. Translation of letter dated Sth Safar 1331, H=16th January 1913, from the French Consul, Maskat, to His Highness the Sultan of Maskat. After compliments. —I have been honoured in the receipt of your letter dated the 7th of Safar and your friend has understood v hat you mention therein. We have asked your servant Menasche and he says that he has no claim against your servant Vram. His claim is against the customs on y an this thousand rupees is between him and Vram, Inot betw een him and the4 customs. And he asks of your kindness the reply about his former claims and information about the cause of the delay because he has not taken possession of the o-oods which the Superintendent of Customs handed oyer to Abdur Rahim nor their price nor the goods which he handed over to Vram nor their price. 'As for your question with regard to Vram, I have no doubt that Your Highness has authority over him to the seizure of his goods. Usual ending. A. JEANHIER. True translation. S. G. KNOX, Major, Political Agent and Jlis Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat. Sub-Enclosure 3. Enclosure l 2 (3rd letter) to letter No. 19, dated 3Gth January 1913, from the Political Agent, Maskat, to the address of the Political Resident and His Britannic Majesty's Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. Translation of letter dated 16th Safar 1331, M.=24th January 1913, from the French Consul, Maskat, to His Highness the Sultan of Maskat. After compliments. —I am honoured in the receipt of your letter dated the 15th Safar and your friend has understood what you mentioned that the account is finished and settled between Abdul Karim and Menasche. And the two were present with me and Menasche said that it lias not been cleared and at the time of his presence for the purpose of the account between him and Abdul Karim it was clear to him that Abdul Karim did not intend to settle the account which referred to Abdul Rahim nor that which referred to YYram and when he ascertained this he refrained from paying the customs account which is for 1,682 dollars, so that Abdul Karim may consent to the payment of the aforesaid sums and Menasche has been delayed from his journey by these hindrances which have been prolonged without result. Now as Your Majesty wishes from us the compulsion of Menasche to pay the aforesaid sum and likewise we ask of your kindness that you should compel Abdul Karim to pay the sums already men tioned and that the payment on both sides should be simultaneous and Menasche says that two boxes of cartridges have been spoilt at the customs which he and Abdul Karim have seen and he desires from him evidence so that the company or someone else should pay for the loss and Abdul Karim does not agree thereto, therefore we ask from your kindness that you should order an enquiry about that and whence this damage came about and be good enough to inform us of the result and may you remain thanked and salaam. A. JEANNIER. True translation. S. G. KNOX, Major, Political Agent, and His Britannic . Majesty's Consul, Maskat. 141 E. D.No. 22, dated Maskat, the 28th January 1913 (Confidential). From —Major S. G. Knox, His Britannic Majesty’s Consul and Political Ao-ent Maskat, & ' To—The Secretary to the Government of India in the Foreign Department, Delhi. I have the honour to submit herewith the copy of letter No. 21, dated the 28th January 1913, which I have addressed to the Political Kesident and His Britannic Majesty’s Consul-General in the Persian Gulf. No. 21, dated Maskat, the 28th January 1913 (Confidential). From— Major S. G. Knox, Political Agent and His Britannic Majesty's Consul at Maskat, To— Lieutenant-Colonel Sir Percy Cox, LA., K.C.I.E., C.S.I., Resident and His Britannic Majesty's Consul-General in the Persian Gulf, Bushire. In continuation of my confidential letter No. 19, dated the 26th January * Forwarded by. wail of 26 t h Wry 1913 the h onou y t o submit the separately to save time. translation of the reply of the I rench Consul, Maskat, to the letter, dated 26th January 1913, which His Highness despatched, under the advise tendered by me m accordance with the instructions contained in Poreign Department telegram No. 52-C., dated 24th January 1913, to my Prench colleague. 2. The reply of my colleague contains nothing new and it would seem that « a correspondence of this kind, in which His Highness puts forward one view of the case ^ to which the Prench Consul rejoins with a directly contrary opinion may continue indefinitely without other result than the undesirable one of fur ther embittering the relations between them. If, however, silence may he inter- \ preted as consent to my colleague’s views and a reply is considered necessary, I would suggest that His Highness might say that Ahdur Rahim is ready, and has always been ready, to pay the Pr. 24,000 which he admits are due from him to Monsieur Menasche and that, with regard to the other matters involved, he and the Prench Consul must, for the present at any rate, unfortunately agree to differ. 3. A copy of this letter, with its enclosure, is being forwarded to the Hon’ble the Secretary to the Government of India in the Poreign Department. {Translation of a letter, dated 18th Sqfar 1331-H.= 26th January 1913. From the French Consul, Maskat, to the address of Sis Highness the Sultan of Maskat). After compliments. —I have been honoured in the receipt of your honoured letter, dated the 18th: Safar 1331-H., and your friend has understood what you have mentioned and I have been excessively astonished at its contents and firstly the custom, but the custom is not a rule upon anybody unless that it is founded upon rule. And the only rule is the treaty between the two Govern ments the Omani and the Prench, no other than it on our subjects. And what you say in the matter of handing over goods without a hill of lading, Your Majesty said that the Customs Department chooses among the merchants and that in their view the more worthy is he who does not hold the bill of lading and the goods will he delivered into the hand of him who has not the right of enjoy ment therein. And your Honour said further if injury falls on your subjects from that procedure, it does not concern the Omani Government. Then is the Customs Department independent and what Customs Department of the Customs Departments is not responsible for such acts and what post office of the post offices hands over the amount of an order to one who is not the hearer thereof ?MM Secondly I have no knowledge that the question in the matter of the new beconaiy, J. nave & I onlv kn0 w and have clearly informed Your arrangement is u ^ G i orious Government has not consented to the New arrangement. Further the claim which is between Menasche and Ahdur Rahim has no connection with this arrangement. Then as the result of all that s iTn^iWc for me to accept the want of the decision from you on account of this arrangement. Then if Ahdul Karim is a merchant of credit as you say, ihen ™ can Pay his debts and your Honour has full authority over him so that he should pay t^e old debt to the Customs and the Customs should pay it to Menasche P But the new debt since Abdur Rahim has broken the conditions of the promise through breach of faith then the goods and the earnest money belong to Mon“eur Menasche according to the rules of the two Governments. Usual ending. A jeaNNIFR. t I f Under* True Translation. S. Gr. KNOX, Major, Political Agent and Sis Britannic Majesty's Consul, Maskat. N, Secretary Oommitt1 In any further communication on this subject, please quote N „. 2047/13. and address— The Under-Secretary of State, Foreign Office, London. P Iqo : D , / Foreign Office January 15th, 1913. Sir: - With reference to your letter of the 13th. instant relative to the arms traffic at Muscat, I am directed by Secretary Sir E. Grey to request you to inform the Secretary of State for India that he concurs in the instructions which the Secretary of State proposes to give to the Government of India, as contained in your letter above-mentioned. I am. Sir, Your most obedient, humble Servant, The Under Secretary of State, India Office.From Viceroy, 7th January 1913. (Repeated to Bushire and Maskat.) Foreign Secret. Maskat Arms Traffic. French Consul has asked Sultan for permission for Menachi, French arms dealer, to ship portion of arms and ammunition now in warehouse to Europe or Jibuti, without prejudice to Menachi’s claim for compensation. We see no objection to reshipment of arms, and Sultan would he glad to be rid of them. But question of customs duty arises. As there _ is nothing in French Treaty to justify exemption, and as warehouse is not bonded warehouse for customs purposes, but storehouse for regulation of arms, trade-duty should he claimed. This will make clear character of warehouse. As regards compensation, Sultan might reply that he has never admitted any claim for compensation, and can say nothing on the subject.

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: File 868/1912 Pt 5 'Arms traffic: Muscat trade. Reshipment of stocks by French dealers. Menasche Fraud.'

mods.abstract: This part of the volume contains telegrams, despatches, correspondence, memoranda, notes, printed reports and two press-cuttings relating to the arms traffic in Muscat and arrangements for its regulation.Issues discussed include:the suspension of the Sultan's regulations pending arbitration and the Foreign Office's response to a French proposal;French schemes to evade the Sultan of Muscat's regulations by trans-shipment;Amendment for rule 5 of the Muscat Warehouse regulations;Anglo-French diplomacy and proposed cession of territory in neighbourhood of Pondicherry;value of weapons stock held in the Warehouse and disposals of the stocks after compilation of inventory;negotiations with the French over compensation and agreement concluded on 14 February 1914 through an exchange of notes;arrangements to delay publication of agreement until after elections in France;enquiry from Belgian Ministries concerning the Brussels Conference 1908-09.the French 'Yellow Book' on the Muscat Arms Traffic Question (ff 72-107).
